Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.time_to_resolution: Approximately 14 months (prediction as of September 2025; question resolves on November 2025 CPI release, likely mid-December 2025).
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.perspective_relevance: As a central banking (Fed monetary policy) expert, my insights are tightly linked to how the Fed weighs a deteriorating labor market, Trump administration pressures, and the impact of tariffs/tax/spending policy on inflation. My expertise informs the mechanics and lags of monetary policy, the feedback loops between labor slack and price pressures, and the risks or likely magnitude of transitory versus sustained inflation.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.status_quo: The 12-month US CPI was 2.73258% in November 2024, and as of August 2025 stands at 2.9%. The typical path (base rate) is for year-on-year inflation to be flat to down after a tariff/inflation spike, especially amid labor market weakening and monetary easing.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Modestly increases inflation through 2025, but most of the tariff shock appears to be a one-off price level increase, not a sustained rise. Recent evidence shows many firms are absorbing costs and producer price inflation is cooling, limiting further CPI acceleration.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor market deterioration and GDP slowdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases inflation. The slump in job growth, negative revisions, and rising unemployment (projected near 4.5% for 2025), plus slow GDP (CBO: 1.4% in 2025), are historically disinflationary, putting downward pressure on wage growth and consumer demand.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed's shift to rate cuts under political and economic pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly decreases inflation by easing rates, but the main effect is to stabilize or soften the downturn. With past Fed cuts, there is usually about a 9-12 month lag before a discernible effect on inflation; the timing aligns for late 2025. However, if the cuts are perceived as premature, there is some risk of import price rises.

Broadly decreases probability of sustained inflation. In the last several decades, CPI annual inflation rarely rises for two consecutive years after a shock, unless accompanied by a commodity/energy crisis, which is not the case now.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Potential one-off price level increases due to tax and immigration policy
perspective_derived_factors.effect: May sustain slightly higher inflation for several months, especially in goods, but fading as demand cools and inventories normalize.

Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.no_scenario: Inflation remains sticky or re-accelerates: The Fed's rate cuts (especially under White House pressure) re-ignite inflation expectations or a late-year energy/commodity price shock reinforces price momentum. Alternatively, persistent pass-through of tariffs to consumer prices and business inability to absorb further costs drive the 12-month CPI for November 2025 higher than the 2.73% base in 2024. Labor market slack is not enough to sharply dampen aggregate demand, so inflation stays elevated into late 2025.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.yes_scenario: Disinflation resumes as expected: The tariff pass-through proves to be largely a one-off or front-loaded to earlier months, with commodity and core goods inflation fading by late 2025. The jobs market continues to soften, unemployment rises above 4.5%, wage growth decelerates further, and aggregate demand falls below trend. Fed rate cuts support sentiment but arrive too late in the year to prevent further cooling. By November 2025, the 12-month CPI annual reading slips below the 2.73% of the prior year, perhaps closer to 2.3–2.6%, matching or undershooting CBO/market consensus.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.final_reasoning: Bringing together central banking base rates, current data showing a cooling labor market, the contained pass-through of tariffs, and Fed/economic forecasts, the most likely scenario is that US year-on-year CPI in November 2025 is lower than in November 2024. Historically, inflation spikes on supply shocks do not persist when real economic activity and labor markets weaken, and monetary policy pivots dovishly—the prevailing situation. There is a non-negligible risk that inflation remains stubborn (risk: energy/commodity shock, or inflation expectations unanchored by Fed/Trump friction), but this is outweighed by the momentum of disinflation and the cooling economy. The base rate, CBO projections, and Moody’s/market consensus (most expect CPI to be 2.3–2.7% by late 2025) all align with a Yes outcome. Given the possibility of sticky or volatile components, the forecast should not be maximally extreme but moderately confident.

Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months until November 2025 CPI data is released (~12 months after November 2024).
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).perspective_relevance: As an expert in central banking, particularly in the dynamics of Fed forward guidance, I bring insight into how monetary policy, real-time economic indicators, and central bank communication interact to influence inflation expectations and actual inflation outcomes. A nuanced reading of how the Fed reacts to dual mandate risks—unemployment and inflation—guided by their latest statements and projections, is crucial in handicapping the direction of year-on-year inflation.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).status_quo: The latest available 12-month CPI change (November 2024) was 2.73%. Unless there is a significant shift in macroeconomic conditions, inflation tends to be sticky. Fed tightening in 2023–24 and weakening labor markets into 2025 should, in the absence of big shocks, bias inflation downward or at least keep it stable.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed Forward Guidance and Rate Cuts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed—Near-term dovishness (rate cuts starting September 2025) should create looser financial conditions, but lagged effects and soft credit/labor market data mean this may not immediately spur price acceleration. The Fed's clear messaging, with Powell's emphasis on one-time tariff shocks and no signs of a persistent inflationary spiral, makes a major renewed upswing less likely before November 2025.

Inflationary—Tariffs and reduced immigration (tighter labor supply) have contributed to an upshift in inflation in summer 2025 (CPI 2.9% in August), with multiple economists warning that pass-through effects are not done. Most forecasts see 2025 inflation running higher than last year.

Disinflationary—Job growth materially weaker than previously reported (900k downward BLS revision), jump in jobless claims, rising unemployment all signal slack that should reduce wage pressures and consumer demand. CBO and many private forecasts project CPI returning to or below 2.5% by late 2025/2026.
Disinflationary—Historically, when US year-on-year CPI is in the 2.5–3.0% range and labor markets deteriorate, the dominant scenario is stabilization or a modest downward trend in inflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: One-off Tariff Pass-through versus Persistent Effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Disinflationary—Fed and analysts consider recent inflation pickup as mainly a one-time level increase, not a sustained pace, with much pass-through already absorbed (firms absorbing costs, slower final price pass-through, some reversal in PPI).

Neutral to mildly inflationary in near term—Headline CPI has risen due to food, energy, used car prices, but core has been stickier around 3.1%. However, recent data show producer and import prices cooling, which may soon translate to headline relief. Shelter inflation is decelerating, which is key to future months.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Forward-looking Market and Model-Based Inflation Forecasts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Disinflationary—Market-implied inflation expectations (5y breakevens) remain anchored. Moody’s, CBO, and private sector forecasts cluster around 3.1% for 2025 on average but expect a gentle deceleration towards late 2025.

Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).no_scenario: Trump's tariff increases create more persistent upward pressure into Q4 2025, labor market weakness is overshadowed by strong consumer demand or late cost pass-through. The Fed's autumn rate cuts spark a rebound in housing, wage gains re-accelerate, or another exogenous shock (oil, supply chain) hits. As a result, headline CPI for November 2025 prints at or above 2.73%—even as economic conditions deteriorate.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).yes_scenario: Tariff-induced inflation is largely a one-time or already-absorbed shock, labor market softness accelerates, consumer demand cools further, core elements such as shelter decelerate, and looser Fed policy fails to reflate inflation immediately. Year-on-year comparisons become easier (base effects), CPI growth moderates, and November 2025 comes in below November 2024's 2.73%. This is reinforced if producer prices stay soft and no new shocks emerge.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).final_reasoning: Despite the summer up-tick in headline CPI (to 2.9% in August), the underlying context is one where the Fed is now cutting rates explicitly on labor market weakness, not on fear of entrenched inflation. Multiple FOMC members, as well as Powell, signal that tariff effects are mainly one-off, not a trigger for a wage-price spiral. Recent downward revisions to jobs data, rising jobless claims, and a projected slowdown in GDP and hiring into late 2025 create powerful disinflationary momentum. Most published public and private forecasts (CBO: 3.1% annual average but decelerates into late 2025/2026) expect inflation to moderate, and base effects become more favorable in the year-on-year prints by late 2025. While near-term prints (July–September) are pressured upwards by tariffs and energy, there is strong reason to assign higher weight to the probability that November 2025 y/y inflation is at or somewhat below 2.73%. Historically, after similar mild inflation surges, with central banks remaining vigilant and labor slack rising, inflation reverses, with only brief, rare exceptions. Current forward guidance, monetary/credit conditions, and the absence of new shocks point to stabilization or gentle decline. Considering the latest data, the balance of risks, and central banking historical patterns, I am confident the resolution will be Yes, but not with extreme certainty, allowing for some risk inflation remains flat or slightly up.

US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.time_to_resolution: Approximately 14 months (question will resolve after the BLS releases November 2025 CPI data, typically mid-December 2025).
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US Economic Statistics and specifically the Bureau of Labor Statistics' CPI methodology, I bring a nuanced understanding of how monthly and annual inflation rates are constructed, how structural factors (tariffs, labor, shocks) can pass through to the headline numbers, and how revisions or compositional shifts in the CPI basket as well as base effects can drive changes even in turbulent macro environments. I can also assess how policy (Fed rate cuts, tariffs) translates into consumer prices, and recognize systematic lags in the CPI data because of BLS updating practices.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.status_quo: As of November 2024, 12-month CPI inflation is 2.73%. The most common outcome when inflation is near but above target is for it to remain roughly steady or to move slowly—base rates suggest stability or slow drift around this value, barring exogenous price shocks or policy changes.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability inflation is higher in Nov 2025 than Nov 2024. Multiple articles and economists note that Trump's new tariffs (10% broad, plus more targeted hikes) are making their way into goods prices, with cars, apparel, furniture, and food explicitly cited as rising in recent data. CBO and other forecasters project this remains a pro-inflationary force through 2025.

Decreases probability of higher inflation. The BLS employment benchmark revision shows job growth was far weaker than reported, with outright job losses in some months and unemployment rising to ~4.3%. With labor market slack increasing and wage pressures ebbing, demand-driven inflation is likely to moderate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed Rate Cuts and Monetary Policy Accommodations
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambivalent effect (slightly increases inflation). While rate cuts would normally stoke inflation, recent commentary from the Fed and market analysts indicates the cuts are in response to economic weakness, thus demand boost may be limited. Nevertheless, easier money could support somewhat higher inflation barring a recession.

Slightly decreases probability of persistent high inflation. Both Powell and market economists note that tariff-driven inflation is frequently a one-time price shock. BLS methodology means that YoY CPI will only compare base levels—if tariffs' full effect is already felt by mid-2025, then YoY comparisons from Nov 2025 to Nov 2024 may not be much higher.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Effects and Mathematical Properties of 12-month Change
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases uncertainty, but potentially slightly lowers probability of higher inflation. If inflation picked up in late 2024 and stays moderate in 2025, then YoY inflation could fall, even if average monthly inflation is persistent but not accelerating.
Increases probability of higher inflation. Both forecast CPI in 2025 above the Nov 2024 level: CBO sees 3.1% for 2025, and Moody’s suggests tariff and policy pass-through push annual rates to 3.5%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Goods vs. Services Inflation and Structural Factors
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambivalent. Goods inflation is rising due to tariffs, but some categories (e.g., housing) comprise large CPI shares and may see moderation if the economy slows—BLS methodology gives shelter high weight, so developments in rental markets could disproportionately move the index lower.

US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.no_scenario: Despite tariffs and labor disruptions, supply chains normalize, and weak consumer demand plus soft rental markets allow inflation to stabilize or decline by Q3/Q4 2025. Monthly CPI increases come in below annualized 2.7% by mid-2025, bringing the November 2025 YoY rate below 2.73%. Tariff pass-through is largely complete by late 2024 or early 2025, so base effects help bring year-on-year changes down. Core goods inflation fades as firms absorb more costs and global disinflation resumes, while Fed cuts support labor and mitigate further pass-through.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.yes_scenario: Tariff pass-through proves persistent or even intensifies as importers run down inventory stockpiles, and major goods categories keep posting monthly CPI gains above trend through mid/late 2025. Shelter and food inflation remain sticky as immigration curbs tighten the labor supply and push up wage and service costs. Fed cuts fail to meaningfully stimulate growth but provide just enough support to prevent outright demand destruction, so inflation hovers at or above 2.7% through November 2025. Alternatively, energy prices spike on geopolitical shocks, adding to headline CPI. Result: November 2025 YoY CPI > November 2024, with print near the 3% region, in line with CBO and Moody’s projections.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.final_reasoning: The base rate, supported by historical CPI time series, is that once inflation subsides toward the Fed's target, it tends to be sticky—especially absent commodity price shocks. However, multiple sources and the CBO now expect that Trump’s tariffs and restrictive immigration policies will create ongoing, not merely one-off, price pressures through much of 2025. The current trend is upwards: CPI rose from 2.7% in June/July to 2.9% in August despite a weakening labor market, suggesting tariff effects are flowing through even as demand slows. Models from CBO and Moody’s, projecting 3.1%–3.5% for 2025, suggest the consensus expects inflation to rise above (not below) current levels. Structural labor market weakness could exert strong downward pressure on inflation if slack proves larger than anticipated and rental markets crack quickly, but the mix of factors points to persistent goods/service inflation offsetting this, particularly given the policy environment of mild monetary easing and fiscal stimulus. The effect of base effects is less likely to help: since inflation ticked up during summer 2024, the YoY comparison for Nov 2025 will need outright monthly CPI declines by mid/late 2025 to push the 12-month change below 2.73%. BLS methodology amplifies this lagged effect. Given the outlook, it is most likely—based on public forecasts, current YoY trajectory, and BLS construction—that November 2025 CPI inflation will be equal to or higher than November 2024 (2.73%). A 'No' remains plausible; recession risk is elevated, and a shallow to moderate recession could see CPI fall. But the balance of credible projections, BLS index inertia, and public experts’ consensus puts the odds of inflation falling below 2.73% by next November as distinctly sub-50%.

US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.time_to_resolution: About 2 months until the release of November 2025 CPI data (typically published mid-December 2025), so approximately 3 months until resolution.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.perspective_relevance: As a CBO forecasting expert, I ground estimates in macroeconomic modeling, base rates, and attention to policy dynamics, giving special weight to official CBO projections, the lagged effect of policy shocks (tariffs, immigration), monetary/interest rate adjustments, and labor market conditions. This expertise helps integrate historical inflation dynamics with rigorous, institutional outlooks calibrated against structural, not transitory, drivers of inflation.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.status_quo: The 12-month percentage change in US CPI in November 2024 is 2.73258%. Inflation in recent years (pre-pandemic: 1.5–2.5%; 2021–22 spiked; 2023–25 has moderated) had been trending downward post-pandemic but is now under renewed upward pressure from new policy shocks (tariffs, immigration crackdowns.).

perspective_derived_factors.effect: The CBO, in its latest report, projects annual inflation at 3.1% for 2025 (calendar year average), above the 2.7% as of November 2024, nudging the probability toward 'No.' This is informed by modeling in response to new Trump tariffs and immigration policy dampening supply.

Monthly and 12-month CPI have ticked up: 2.9% y/y in August 2025, a climb from ~2.7% in June/July and 2.73% in November 2024. This momentum suggests a continued near-term upward drift, lowering odds for a Y/Y November 2025 drop.

Policymakers are (per Powell, FOMC, and Fed staff) increasingly comfortable that tariff-induced inflation will be mostly one-time, but the full pass-through may not be exhausted by November 2025, and firms have started to pass on costs (as seen in cars, clothes, groceries). This delays disinflation, keeping year-on-year CPI elevated.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor market cooling and job losses
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Sharp job market slowdown (major downward revisions, near-stall in job gains, rising unemployment) generally creates downward pressure on inflation (via slack, demand destruction)—this would support a drop in CPI. But so far, consumer spending has held up and supply-side shocks are dominating.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed policy (interest rates and forward guidance)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Fed is cutting, under pressure and in response to labor market weakness. Typically, lower interest rates would support demand and be inflationary, but in the near-term, rate cuts are a response to deteriorating labor demand—so they may not stoke inflation immediately. Cuts may support CPI in late 2025, but not enough to dramatically reverse recent increases.

Recent reports show some corporate absorption of tariff costs (PPI lower than expected), partly muting consumer price rises. However, some pass-through has already materialized and absorption may be unsustainable in the face of margin compression—risking further upward pressure.

Historically, once inflation ticks up due to policy/drives, it rarely reverses within a single year unless there is a sharp policy pivot or recession. This base rate lowers the probability of a November-to-November decline following a fresh policy shock.

US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.no_scenario: CPI continues the modest upward trajectory of recent months, remaining above (or at) 2.7% in November 2025, propelled by lingering tariff impacts, wage rigidity, and only gradual economic cooling. Firms increasingly pass through tariff costs, and labor market slack is insufficient to offset upward pressure. Even with Fed cuts, disinflation is slow due to persistent supply-side shocks.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.yes_scenario: Unexpectedly aggressive disinflation driven by collapsing consumer and business demand, rapid layoff-induced labor market slack, and deeper recessionary tendencies. Tariff pass-through proves minimal as global input prices fall; firms cut prices to maintain sales. Fed rate cuts plus declining real wages deliver weak demand and cause CPI to fall below November 2024 levels.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.final_reasoning: The CBO baseline (most authoritative, impartial quantitative projection) puts 2025 inflation over 2024's level. Recent CPI and core readings confirm a modest but measurable new upward drift since mid-2025 aligned with policy shocks (tariffs, immigration). The pass-through of tariffs still appears incomplete, and business absorption only partially muting consumer impacts. The labor market, while weakening, has not translated into outright recession or outright collapse in demand, though risks are rising. Interest rate cuts in late 2025 are lagged in impact, and are more defensive than stimulative under these conditions. The base rate argues strongly against an annual inflation drop in the year following major supply-side shocks unless a major recession sets in immediately. As a CBO policy forecast analyst, these factors together compel a probability clearly below 50%, but not near zero—there's tail risk from a sudden recession or global demand collapse. The median scenario is continued but moderate CPI elevation through late 2025.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).time_to_resolution: About 11 months (until Nov 2025 data is released, likely in mid-December 2025)
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist specializing in the Phillips Curve, I focus on the interplay among inflation, unemployment, and monetary policy. This lens is crucial here, as the Phillips Curve traditionally posits an inverse relationship between unemployment and inflation. However, recent evidence and structural changes, like global supply shocks and policy interventions (tariffs, immigration restrictions), must be integrated for a nuanced inflation forecast.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).status_quo: The 12-month change in the US CPI in November 2024 is 2.73258%. As of the latest available data, CPI inflation has drifted upward (2.9% in August 2025), exceeding the status quo and above the Fed target. Policy responses (Fed rate cuts) are emerging due to labor market weakness. The base rate for year-on-year US inflation dropping from one year to the next is historically high in non-shock periods, but less predictable when inflation is near target and headline numbers are recently rising.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Weakening Labor Market and Rising Unemployment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases inflation probability; higher unemployment should moderate wage growth and dampen inflationary pressures over the coming quarters per the Phillips Curve framework. Data now show clear job market deterioration: large downward revisions to job growth, rising jobless claims, and unemployment now at ~4.3–4.5%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Tariff Increases and Immigration Restrictions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases inflation probability; tariffs directly raise import costs and can cause upward price pressure (especially as corporate absorption capacity diminishes over time). Immigration restrictions further tighten the labor market in some sectors, risking upward wage/price pressure.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Onset of Easing Monetary Policy (Rate Cuts)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous: Typically, rate cuts would boost inflation, but here they are motivated by real-side weakness (recessionesque conditions). The transmission from lower rates to higher prices could be muted if consumer demand continues to weaken. Forward guidance and lagged effects mean any stimulative impact will be felt late in the period or beyond.

Increases probability inflation is stable or higher in Nov 2025 vs Nov 2024; CPI has ticked up from Spring 2025 lows (2.7%) to 2.9% in August, with core at 3.1%. Headline numbers may have a stickiness or inertia effect, particularly if cost-push from tariffs persists.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Producer Price Index and Business Absorption of Tariffs
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases likelihood of sustained inflation; recent PPI has been cooler than CPI forecasts, suggesting many businesses are eating costs, and that pass-through may not be as direct. This supports a less inflationary scenario over the next 12 months if retail pricing power remains weak.

Slightly increases probability of higher inflation; CBO projects 3.1% inflation for 2025, up from the current Nov 2024 value, and private estimates are in the 3–3.5% range. Market measures (inflation swaps, breakevens) are elevated. However, forecasters often overreact to recent inflation jumps—base effects could moderate in late 2025.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).no_scenario: Inflation accelerates on a year-over-year basis: Tariff-driven supply shocks outweigh weakening demand, perhaps with exogenous boosts from energy or food prices, continued tight labor markets due to immigration restrictions, and/or an accommodative Fed is late to respond. The labor market stabilizes or rebounds in Q2-Q3 2025, giving firms cover to pass on more costs. As a result, CPI in Nov 2025 is equal to or above 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).yes_scenario: Economic weakness or outright recession dominates: The labor market further deteriorates (unemployment above 4.5–5%), consumer demand weakens sharply, producing strong Phillips Curve effects. Tariff pass-through is muted further by substitution, margin compression, or supply chain adjustments. The Fed rate cuts have limited immediate impact on price pressures due to weak demand. CPI decelerates in late 2025, with core inflation also softening. Nov 2025 CPI YoY comes in below 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).final_reasoning: At present, signals are mixed but slightly tilted toward continued inflation persistence or even a modest increase. The base rate for inflation slowing YoY, particularly after an acceleration associated with policy shocks (tariffs, immigration), is modestly below 50%: the CBO and consensus forecasts see inflation above 2.73% in 2025. Tariff and immigration shocks are still passing through and, while some business absorption is visible (via PPI), CPI has ticked up recently and labor market tightness from immigration policies may continue to add wage pressure in sticky sectors. However, the Phillips Curve is not entirely dead: with the jobs market weakening significantly, it's plausible that demand-side disinflation restores the trend by late 2025. I discount extreme outcomes (deep recession, rapid deflation, or surging 4%+ inflation), and overweight recent trends alongside structural persistence from tariffs. Therefore, I put the chances of YoY CPI in Nov 2025 being lower than Nov 2024 (i.e., below 2.73258%) at about 35%, reflecting a modestly pessimistic (inflation-persistence) base scenario with non-trivial risk of a downside (disinflationary) surprise due to labor market and demand-side cooling.

Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).time_to_resolution: Approx. 2 months (until the US CPI for November 2025 is published, generally mid-December 2025; as of forecast date: 2025-09-15)
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory), I focus on the role of money, monetary policy, and expectations in determining inflation. Monetarist analysis prioritizes the medium-run effect of monetary aggregates and central bank policy on price levels, and gives extra weight to the persistence of inflation, the importance of public inflation expectations, and the inertia of the Phillips Curve. This perspective offers a disciplined approach for interpreting the likely trajectory of US CPI in the coming year, especially amid political intervention, supply shocks (tariffs), labor market softness, and shifting monetary stances.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).status_quo: Inflation is annualizing at 2.73% as of November 2024, with decelerating momentum in early 2024 but a rebound mid-2025 due to tariff policy. The base case in stable times is mean reversion toward the Fed’s 2% target, but recent months have seen inflation tick up (August 2025 y/y CPI at 2.9%). Historically, annual US CPI changes are sticky and tend to move slowly absent major shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed monetary policy shift toward easing in late 2025
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability inflation will be lower in Nov 2025 than Nov 2024 (possible lagged effects of easier money starting late 2025 may appear in 2026, but dovish guidance will support inflation expectations in the short run)

Decreases probability (supports above-2.7% inflation over next 12 months), as tariffs lift import prices and may feed through to consumer goods gradually, especially as inventories run down and cost absorption fades.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Weakening labor market and below-potential GDP growth
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability (tends to reduce wage/price pressure; unemployment revisions point to negative output gap forming; monetary transmission lags could start reducing inflation into late 2025 if demand falters).
Increases probability (if businesses and markets believe inflation will subside, actual pricing behavior moderates, limiting persistence; evidence suggests long-term expectations remain near 2-2.3%).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Pass-through and persistence of tariff effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed; tariff pass-through so far has been partial (firms absorbing costs), but some evidence of delayed passthrough emerging. The magnitude and duration of this pass-through is uncertain, but monetarists expect these to be one-time (level) effects absent sustained monetary accommodation. Overall, increases probability that inflation could revert lower after adjustment, though near-term risks are to the upside.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical base rate for US CPI to be lower after temporary spikes
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability; in past 20 years, when CPI jumps due to external shocks (e.g., energy, tariffs), it tends to come down over the following year unless monetary policy is sharply expansionary.

Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).no_scenario: Tariffs continue or increase, and cost passthrough accelerates as inventories drawn down, with firms forced to raise prices further into late 2025. The Fed, although easing, does so too late (transmission lag) or the cuts are not enough to sharply slow demand. Additionally, wage growth remains stubborn, keeping core services inflation elevated. CPI prints for August–November 2025 match or exceed recent monthlies (0.3–0.4%), keeping Nov 2025 y/y CPI above 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).yes_scenario: The recent inflation uptick proves transitory as the bulk of tariff passthrough occurs by September, and weak labor market (job losses, low hiring) causes demand to soften further into Q4, with the Fed's rate cuts reinforcing inflation expectations rather than feeding new demand. Monthly CPI gains cool to 0.1–0.2% through autumn, and year-over-year CPI for November 2025 comes in below 2.73% (e.g., if monthly m/m CPI growth averages ~0.15–0.2% from Sept to Nov, y/y CPI could fall below Nov 2024’s level). Historical patterns after one-off shocks (tariffs, energy) and labor sag support this reversion if monetary policy remains broadly consistent.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).final_reasoning: The status quo trajectory has shifted since early 2024, with recent months seeing a modest but non-trivial inflation uptick (from 2.7% in June/July to 2.9% y/y in August), attributed largely to tariff passthrough and mild food/energy gains. However, the labor market shows notable weakness—job growth is at stall speed, major downward revisions to employment, and rising unemployment claims. These output gap signals typically dampen inflation with a short lag. Current monetary policy is turning more accommodative, but given lags, its inflationary impact is more material for 2026 than late 2025. Tariff passthrough, while not trivial, appears to be a level shift more than a sustained inflation impulse, per both recent PPI/CPI data and Fed guidance. Historical base rates indicate that inflation is more likely to fall after temporary externally driven spikes if demand weakens and the central bank does not overreact with excessive stimulus. Inflation expectations remain fairly well anchored, mitigating the risk of a persistent spiral. Weighing these factors, especially the labor market cooling and partial, not runaway, tariff passthrough, I judge the probability that Nov 2025’s annual CPI will be lower than in Nov 2024’s 2.73% as slightly above even, but not decisively so: the risk of persistent supply-side price pressures offset by rising disinflationary demand forces and a cautious (not aggressive) monetary response.

Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months, until the release of the US CPI report for November 2025 (expected mid-December 2025)
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist specializing in New Keynesian models, my approach integrates the dynamic interplay of monetary policy, supply-side shocks (tariffs, labor market), and expectations formation. In New Keynesian frameworks, forward-looking behavior, nominal rigidities, and the centrality of expectations are crucial for understanding inflation outcomes, and I am attuned to how monetary-fiscal shocks transmit through the broader economy and into headline inflation figures.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).status_quo: The 12-month CPI inflation for November 2024 is 2.73%. Barring sustained shocks, US inflation has shown a moderate downward trend since mid-2022, as the Fed raised rates to above-neutral, and post-pandemic supply disruptions have largely unwound. The status quo expectation would be for a slow drift lower or stable inflation if policy and external shocks remained moderate.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of higher or persistent inflation. Tariffs drive up import costs, which can be passed to consumers either immediately or with a lag. Recent news suggests these effects are now more muted than anticipated, with some costs being absorbed by firms, but the full pass-through could still sustain elevated inflation.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Cooling labor market and negative employment revisions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases inflation probability. Sharp slowdowns in job growth and upward revisions to unemployment signal less wage pressure and weaker aggregate demand, consistent with disinflation in New Keynesian Phillips curve logic.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed monetary policy pivot (anticipated or actual easing)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed impact. Rate cuts, especially if not justified by fundamentals, can weaken the currency and boost demand, potentially offsetting disinflation from labor market slack. However, if slack is high and expectations are anchored, the impact on inflation may be delayed or moderate.

Decreases higher inflation probability. Historically, US inflation rarely accelerates meaningfully at this stage of the cycle unless there is either a large supply shock or a strong demand resurgence. After transitory shocks, reversion to trend is common.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: One-off vs. persistent effect of tariffs
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability of sustained higher inflation. The consensus among Fed officials and private forecasters is that tariff-driven price increases are largely one-off in nature, and once they are in the price level, future year-on-year inflation will see these effects drop out.

Slightly increases probability of persistence. August CPI came in at 2.9%, up from July, implying some short-term momentum, though most experts see this as driven by a few categories (autos, groceries) and only partially the tariffs.

Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).no_scenario: Inflation remains sticky or ticks up further due to continued pass-through of tariffs to consumers, persistent supply-side pressures (such as new tariffs, further shocks to imports), or an unexpected rebound in consumer demand (possibly due to fiscal stimulus or rate cuts reviving spending) that outpaces the slack from the cooling labor market. In this scenario, the 12-month CPI for November 2025 is the same as or higher than the 2.73% rate reported in November 2024.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).yes_scenario: Disinflationary forces from the substantially weaker labor market, rising unemployment, and negative revisions to job growth dominate, with firms unable to pass on further cost increases to consumers. The prior round of tariff-driven price hikes fades from the year-on-year calculation, leading the 12-month CPI for November 2025 to fall below the previous year's rate, even if headline prints remain above the Fed's 2% target.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).final_reasoning: We are entering a period where headline inflation has recently accelerated (2.9% as of August, highest in several months), but the majority of forward-looking indicators — labor market softening, historic negative jobs revision, retail sales stalling, and the upcoming anticipated rate cuts — all point toward a weakening demand environment typical in New Keynesian models as the Phillips curve steepens during higher slack. The key risk to a lower November 2025 inflation is the persistence of supply-side shocks (specifically, tariffs), but Fed and CBO commentary, along with the producer price data and consensus surveys, suggest that the largest impacts are likely one-off and are already cycling into base effects, making 12-month inflation more likely to subside in late 2025. Furthermore, the CBO and Moody’s forecasts both expect a moderation or decline in inflation in 2026, which means November 2025 is sitting at the inflection point as these effects roll off. While new tariffs or a policy misstep could sustain inflation, base rate logic and the preponderance of disinflationary forces suggest the more probable outcome is a lower year-on-year CPI by November 2025. The recent uptick in inflation is likely a lagged effect of tariffs and pass-through, but weakening demand and base effects should drive the number lower year-over-year — in keeping with New Keynesian predictions when slack is rising. Therefore, the probability is tilted toward 'Yes', but not with high confidence, as short-run fluctuations and further shocks remain possible.

Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).time_to_resolution: Approximately 14 months (question resolves with November 2025 CPI data, reference date is September 15, 2025).
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).perspective_relevance: As an expert in interest rate transmission, my analysis focuses on how changes in monetary policy influence real economic variables—especially inflation—by affecting aggregate demand, expectations, credit, and other transmission channels. The current environment is highly informative as it features both an activist US administration exerting pressure on the Fed and significant policy changes—namely, higher tariffs, immigration crackdowns, and fiscal/tax measures—while the Fed is torn between addressing rising inflation and a rapidly weakening labor market.
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).status_quo: The 12-month percentage change in CPI in November 2024 is 2.73%. Historically, annual CPI inflation has trended downward after exogenous shocks (e.g., post-COVID, energy shocks) unless there is persistent demand-side pressure, with core inflation playing a critical role in the trend. The status quo would be moderate inflation, near 2.7-3.1% annually, with potential for mean reversion absent continued shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed Rate Cuts and Transmission Lags
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases the probability of lower inflation by late 2025. Rate cuts typically ease monetary conditions, but their impact on inflation tends to arrive with a 12 month lag. Recent and anticipated cuts, in response to labor market weakness, may support demand somewhat, but the initial effect of financial stress is likely disinflationary or even mildly deflationary in the medium term (late 2025).

Decreases probability of lower inflation (i.e., tariff shock is inflationary in the short- to medium-term as cost-push pressures flow into consumer prices). However, the evidence from the news and recent CPI/PPI data is that the passthrough has been much lower than expected so far—possibly due to retailers/wholesalers absorbing costs, moderating its effect.

Increases probability of lower inflation. The rapid cooling in job creation (near-stall speed), increased jobless claims, and CBO projections of rising unemployment (to 4.5% in 2025) imply reduced wage pressure and weaker aggregate demand, reinforcing a disinflationary impulse in the coming year.

Decreases probability of lower inflation in the near term. Tax cuts and the outflow of immigrants theoretically produce higher labor costs and aggregate demand. However, countervailing forces (weaker GDP growth down from 2.5% in 2024 to 1.4% in 2025 per CBO) may blunt this effect, suggesting overall impact may be neutral to mildly inflationary.

Increases probability of lower inflation. After cost-push/supply shocks (e.g., new tariffs), US inflation historically reverts downward within 12-18 months as demand adjusts and the labor market softens. Current levels (2.73%-2.9%) are above the Fed’s target, but not far off historical norms prior to major supply shocks.

Decreases probability of rapid disinflation. Sticky prices (shelter, insurance, services) continue to see upward pressure, complicating the path to lower headline CPI even with weaker demand. However, if labor market weakness persists, rents and some services may decelerate into 2025.

Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).no_scenario: Tariff passthrough accelerates through 2025, as retailers run out of margin to absorb costs and push price increases onto consumers. Fiscal/tax stimulus and continued demand in key sectors (e.g., AI-related investment, select consumer spending) offset labor market weakness. Sticky shelter and insurance costs keep the CPI at or above its late-2024 pace (2.7-2.9%). Core goods inflation re-accelerates or at least fails to subside due to tariff drag, and base effects do not aid disinflation. November 2025 CPI is thus equal to or above November 2024.
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).yes_scenario: Economic weakness deepens more than currently projected, with rising unemployment and stalling wage growth leading to continued or accelerated softening in demand. The Fed’s rate cuts support financial stability, but the credit channel does not recover enough to re-ignite spending, while tariffs prove to be a one-off shock with limited, non-recurring price passthrough. Service inflation cools as rental markets and discretionary consumption weaken. Headline CPI tracks downward into the low-2s or even below by late 2025, with year-on-year inflation dipping below the previous year’s 2.73% figure.
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).final_reasoning: Synthesizing news, base rates, and the mechanics of interest rate transmission, the odds lean toward a modest reduction in headline CPI y/y by November 2025. The major risk to this view is an acceleration in tariff passthrough, but multiple data points (muted PPI, lower-than-feared CPI increases, retailer margin compression) suggest that much of the tariff effect is being absorbed, not passed on, at least so far. The labor market’s rapid deterioration is a much more powerful force in the current equilibrium, as it directly dampens wage and demand-driven inflation. The Fed’s shift to a rate-cutting bias will not immediately re-stimulate demand, and weak growth (CBO: 1.4% for 2025) and higher unemployment should reinforce disinflation. While sticky prices present some downside risk and a reversal is possible—especially if global price or wage shocks occur—the weight of evidence (historically, and in current indicators) supports a base case of slightly lower y/y inflation by late 2025. I assess the probability of a 'Yes' outcome at 68%, acknowledging modest tail risk from renewed supply or tariff shocks but giving greater weight to the disinflationary labor market and the post-tariff-disruption base rate pattern.

Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months, as the November 2025 CPI data will be released in December 2025 and this is September 15, 2025.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Finance, specializing in the Inflation Expectations Hypothesis, my perspective is essential for this forecast. The Inflation Expectations Hypothesis states that actual future inflation is heavily influenced by what households, firms, and market participants expect, which in turn is shaped by monetary policy credibility, recent price shocks, and policy signals. Assessing the credibility and communication of the Federal Reserve, the transmission of recent tariff shocks, and the evolving macro environment enables a more nuanced forecast of year-ahead inflation.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.status_quo: The US 12-month CPI inflation for November 2024 was 2.73%. As of August 2025, CPI inflation has been rising (2.9%), and year-to-date inflation has seen a moderate upturn due to new tariffs and policy shifts under Trump. Historically, absent shocks, inflation moves slowly, with mean reversion to target over several quarters.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: INCREASES probability inflation will remain higher, as tariffs are showing up in higher August CPI readings and likely to continue pushing prices upward, at least for goods.
DECREASES probability inflation will be higher, as broader economic weakness, rising unemployment, and weak job gains tend to translate into weaker demand and slower price growth.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal Reserve policy and expectations anchoring
perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability inflation will be higher, as the Fed is signaling (and beginning) rate cuts, but is taking a cautious, data-driven approach, and long-term inflation expectations remain relatively anchored.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base effects and trend in recent CPI
perspective_derived_factors.effect: INCREASES probability inflation will be higher, as recent year-on-year CPI is running above the November 2024 baseline (August 2025: 2.9%), suggesting even with some base effect, November 2025 may also be above last year’s 2.73%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Producer price index (PPI) and business cost absorption
perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability inflation will be higher, as recent PPI data is cooler and evidence that some tariff costs are being absorbed by margins rather than fully passed to consumers reduces risk of persistent inflation jumps.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Changes in immigration and structural labor force trends
perspective_derived_factors.effect: INCREASES probability inflation will be higher, as Trump’s crackdown lowers labor supply, potentially leading to wage pressures and stickier services inflation.

Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.no_scenario: A 'No' outcome arises if the recent inflation uptick proves temporary. For example, tariffs cause a one-off price jump but are absorbed, the weakening labor market sharply curtails consumer demand, unemployment rises to/reaches recessionary levels as forecast, and the Fed’s rate cuts restore confidence in the anti-inflationary commitment. November 2025 CPI comes in at or above 2.73%, perhaps due to stickiness in shelter, medical, or services costs. This is bolstered if energy prices or food costs rise late in the year, or if Trump's tax/fiscal stimulus temporarily spurs demand.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.yes_scenario: A 'Yes' outcome occurs if current inflation is transitory and the economy’s weakness dominates by late 2025. Job losses, higher unemployment, and weaker household demand, combined with businesses further absorbing cost pressures, push monthly inflation rates in late 2025 below those late in 2024. Shelter and services inflation moderate, offsetting lingering goods price effects. With the 12-month CPI readings decelerating as high monthly prints from late 2024 drop out of the calculation, November 2025 CPI comes in below the 2.73% level.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.final_reasoning: The base rate for US YoY CPI dropping year-over-year is close to 50% over long horizons, but the environment is currently inflationary: August 2025 CPI is already at 2.9%, above the Nov 2024 baseline, with August monthly print (0.4%) annualizing to an even higher level if it persisted. Tariff and immigration policy appear to be pushing up prices, especially for goods. However, the labor market’s pronounced weakness, job loss revisions, and recessionary risks should put strong downward pressure on inflation in the coming months. The Fed is responding but remains cautious—some expectations anchoring is likely, yet monetary transmission lags. Most leading forecasts (Moody’s, CBO) expect higher CPI for 2025 than 2024, projecting 3.1% annual inflation for 2025 (against 2.7% end-2024), and much of the market commentary expects lingering tariff effects to keep year-ahead inflation up. While producer price and business absorption may temper the spike, base effects work against a sub-2.73% print unless a pronounced deflation or recession manifests this autumn. Given recent inflation has surprised to the upside, consumer price stickiness, and the slow-moving nature of economic regime shifts, the probability that November 2025 CPI is below 2.73% strikes me as modest. My view—grounded in the inflation expectations channel, which remains above target, policy uncertainty, and the clear upward trajectory in the data—is that the probability of a 'Yes' is distinctly below even odds, but not extremely low, as the economic slowdown could still quickly translate into weaker prices.

Political Science (Political Business Cy.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months (question resolves with November 2025 CPI data, published mid-December 2025).
Political Science (Political Business Cy.perspective_relevance: As a political science expert specializing in political business cycles, I am attuned to the ways that political structures, electoral incentives, and executive influence intersect with macroeconomic policy—particularly in periods of political transition, strong executive intervention, and heightened economic uncertainty. In the present US context, the interaction between President Trump’s aggressive policy stance (on the Fed, tariffs, immigration, and tax/spending) and the Federal Reserve’s actions will likely shape CPI inflation outcomes. Political business cycles theory also cautions to look for electoral and post-electoral effects, and for how governments may try to shape economic performance in their favor.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.status_quo: As of November 2024, the 12-month US CPI change was 2.73%. Through mid-2025, inflation has ticked back up (2.9% annualized in August 2025, according to the latest data). Conventionally, inflation rates exhibit moderate persistence over 12-month windows, and year-over-year changes tend to revert slowly unless major shocks intervene.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increase probability of higher inflation—tariffs act as a tax on imports, which companies initially may absorb but eventually pass to consumers; reduced immigration tightens labor markets, elevating wage and price pressures.

In traditional models, attempts by presidents to stimulate the economy for political gains can spur looser monetary policy, stoking inflation. However, evident Fed resistance and reputational incentives may limit effect—but some cuts under pressure are likely.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor Market Weakness and Downward Growth Revisions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increase probability of lower inflation—substantial downward revisions in employment (almost 1 million fewer jobs), cooling job market, and rising unemployment signal a looming/ongoing recession, which is strongly associated with disinflation in base rates.

Tariff-induced or supply-side price increases tend to raise inflation initially, then effects taper as base effects roll off and demand falters (~12–18 month lags common in business-cycle literature).

With rate cuts anticipated/initiated from September 2025, there is a risk of stoking inflation, but also, lower rates may be a response to sharp economic slowdown. Historical evidence shows that recession-driven rate cuts often coincide with disinflation—even if the first few post-cut months may see sticky inflation.

Historically, persistent increases in US inflation (from this base) are rare without commodity/energy shocks or persistent policy stimulus. Political interference or supply shocks could break this, but are only rarely sustained. One-year ahead CPI falling below the previous year (i.e., disinflation) is a ~60–70% historical base rate, especially given mid-year economic slowdowns.

Political Science (Political Business Cy.no_scenario: ‘No’ scenario: Despite the economic slowdown, the combined effect of tariffs, immigration restraints, and looser monetary policy (Fed rate cuts under political pressure) propagates through wages, input prices, and consumer goods, pushing November 2025 inflation to exceed 2.73%. Firms, pressured by margin squeezes and dwindling labor supply, accelerate price pass-through. Fiscal stimulus (tax cuts/spending increases) adds to demand, outpacing the disinflation from a weaker job market. External shocks (e.g., oil price spike, continued supply bottlenecks) could tip the balance.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.yes_scenario: ‘Yes’ scenario: The US economy continues to cool: Unemployment rises to 4.5% or higher as projected, weak job creation persists, and consumer/business confidence wanes. Diminished demand overcomes tariff effects, and the pass-through of cost increases proves transitory or muted (firms eat costs to preserve market share). Fed rate cuts support financial conditions but cannot counteract cyclical drag; inflation expectations stabilize or fall. The 12-month CPI in November 2025 records at or below 2.7%, reflecting recessionary/near-recessionary conditions.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.final_reasoning: Starting from the base rate—CPI in the US is more likely than not to decelerate year-over-year after a run-up and late-cycle cooling. Current data show inflation at 2.7–2.9% in summer 2025, above November 2024’s 2.73%, but key drivers (weakening labor market, sharply downward job revisions, slowing GDP) strongly point to recession or near-recession over the next six months. Political business cycles logic suggests attempted stimulus (rate cuts, fiscal intervention), but the lag for such measures is typically longer than the remaining period until November (and recessionary/disinflationary forces usually dominate unless stimulus is huge and sustained). Furthermore, tariff-induced inflation appears to be a one-off shock; recent PPI and core CPI numbers remain relatively contained. While risks remain—particularly from further fiscal loosening, another external price shock, or successful White House pressure on the Fed—the more probable outcome is a cyclical disinflation into Q4 2025, as demand wanes and one-off price increases drop out of the year-over-year calculation. I estimate the probability of November 2025 CPI being lower than November 2024 at 68%, reflecting a status quo base rate of disinflation with added weight to the unusual pro-inflationary risks of this cycle.

Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.time_to_resolution: About 2 months (question resolves upon publication of November 2025 CPI data, which will be released mid-December 2025; today is 15 September 2025).
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Science with a focus on Policy Uncertainty Theory, I am attuned to the interplay between political leadership, policy volatility—especially around trade, tariffs, central bank independence, and immigration—and macroeconomic outcomes such as inflation. I weigh not only macroeconomic models, but also the historic base rates, expectational lags, and how actual vs. anticipated policy shifts ripple through economic actors' decisions, especially when uncertainty is elevated. This perspective is critical since the US is currently experiencing substantial policy uncertainty from tariff policy, political pressure on the Fed, immigration restrictions, and potential administrative interventions.
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.status_quo: The 12-month CPI inflation rate in November 2024 was 2.73%. The current (August 2025) CPI year-on-year rate is 2.9%. The base case is that, absent a major shock, US headline CPI inflation fluctuates gradually, with reversion to the mean around the Fed’s 2% target—though shocks can introduce temporary deviations.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Tariff Policy Transmission and its One-off vs. Persistent Effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Tariffs can create upward pressure on prices, but recent data and Fed statements suggest much of the initial shock was absorbed or transitory; expectations are coalescing around the impact being short-term, not persistent, which would limit further inflation acceleration. This factor slightly reduces the probability of CPI being higher in Nov 2025 than Nov 2024.

The sharp negative labor market revisions (900k fewer jobs), rising unemployment, and weak job creation point to a cooling economy. Historically, significant labor market softness tends to dampen inflation as demand wanes—even in the face of earlier price shocks. This increases the probability Nov 2025 CPI will be lower than Nov 2024.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed Policy and Political Pressure (Policy Uncertainty)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Intense White House pressure for rate cuts could prompt dovish shifts, but market data indicates only modest cuts are likely; the Fed appears more focused on labor market deterioration than inflation risk. If easing is miscalibrated or political risk spikes, it could increase inflation risk, but central bank statements and projections show inflation expectations are broadly anchored. This adds modest upward uncertainty but is likely already priced in.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Base Rates and Mean Reversion
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Historically, US CPI inflation (12-month) fluctuates in narrow bands and trends toward the 2% target when there is no massive macro/energy or fiscal shock. After tariff/business-cycle shocks, there is a tendency for inflation to fall back within 1-2 years. This strongly supports a lower likelihood of sustained year-on-year inflation increases.

Immigration crackdowns theoretically tighten the labor market and increase wage pressure. However, new data indicate that wage/price pass-through is limited; much of the price impact appears front-loaded and is being absorbed by margins, not CPI. This adds mild upward pressure but is unlikely to dominate.

CPI has risen from 2.7% in June/July to 2.9% in August, with some pass-through of tariffs, especially in food and goods. But despite this, expert and official forecasts (e.g., CBO, Moody’s) expect inflation to ease over 2026/2027, and real-time data (PPI) shows softening, suggesting further increases may be temporary.

Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.no_scenario: Tariff and immigration shocks prove stickier than expected and Q4 2025 sees further rounds of price increases passed to consumers (possibly due to new tariffs, additional supply chain disruptions, or a second shock like energy prices), while Fed easing triggers a rebound in consumer demand, keeping CPI for Nov 2025 equal to or above Nov 2024 levels (i.e., year-on-year inflation does not fall).
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.yes_scenario: Current price spikes prove to be one-off adjustments; ongoing labor market weakness leads to demand-side drag; tariffs continue to be absorbed by businesses, and producer prices do not feed through to consumers in additional rounds. The Fed eases but avoids being behind the curve, and by November 2025, CPI growth has moderated (e.g., 2.4%-2.6% YoY as forecast in many models), so Nov 2025 CPI is below the 2.73% Nov 2024 baseline.
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.final_reasoning: The base rate for US YoY CPI falling in periods following supply shocks (like tariffs) and a cooling economy is high, especially when inflation expectations remain anchored and there is policy attention to not reignite persistent inflation. Most forecasts (e.g., CBO, Moody’s, Fed projections) expect inflation to moderate into 2026, with explicit projections placing 2025 CPI near or only modestly above the current Nov 2024 level. The main risk to a 'Yes' is a surprise persistence of tariff pass-through or a supply shock, but available evidence suggests most of this has already worked through the system and that labor market slack will dominate in coming months. Contemporary economic news supports the scenario of a cooling labor market, with Fed cuts not expected to stoke enough demand to overwhelm these effects. Thus, status quo and mean reversion logic—augmented by recent labor and inflation data—points toward November 2025 CPI YoY likely being lower than November 2024. I assign a moderate-to-strong probability, reflecting high—but not extreme—confidence.
